title: Paraesophageal Hernia
setup_script: “A 72-year-old woman presents with postprandial chest discomfort, early satiety, and occasional dyspnea. She also has a history of iron deficiency anemia. On initial evaluation, she appears comfortable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 85 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 36.9 °C.
Retrocardiac air–fluid level suggestive of intrathoracic stomach.
Large paraesophageal hernia with gastric fundus in thorax; minimal GE junction displacement.
Cameron ulcers present with mild esophagitis; biopsies obtained.
Iron deficiency anemia with ferritin 10 ng/mL; stool occult blood positive.
Symptomatic paraesophageal hernia with anemia and risk of volvulus; surgical repair recommended.
Laparoscopic reduction, sac excision, crural repair, and fundoplication; mesh reinforcement if defect is large.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe technical steps of operation
dynamic_flow.reply: Resident should detail trocar placement, hernia sac dissection, reduction of stomach, mobilization of esophagus, crural approximation, and fundoplication. Examiner may ask: “Please describe your operative steps in detail.”
Patient at risk for volvulus, strangulation, bleeding, or aspiration pneumonia.
Normal esophageal motility confirmed; guides choice between Nissen vs. Toupet fundoplication.
Gradual diet progression, small frequent meals, monitor for dysphagia and gas-bloat syndrome.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about asymptomatic small hernia
dynamic_flow.reply: Observation with counseling on warning signs is reasonable.
Advises iron supplementation until surgery and importance of follow-up for recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of paraesophageal hernia using imaging and endoscopy
Recognition of surgical indications (symptoms, anemia, risk of volvulus)
Key components of laparoscopic repair and fundoplication
Ability to describe operative steps in detail
Preoperative manometry and tailoring fundoplication type
Postoperative management and counseling on recurrence risk
